Authors: Xiaoling Li, genhua yang, Chengyun Li
Title:
Phylogeny and taxonomy of graminicolous Phyllachora
species
Keywords:
host specificity, hostparasite relationships,
Phyllachoraceae, molecular phylogeny, taxonomy
Abstract:
The genus Phyllachora is consists of obligate biotrophic
fungi with a worldwide distribution. This group of fungi are only
capable of life on living plant, so colonize the aerial part of host
plants, but this only a small part of their life cycle. Even though
members of this genus occur as parasites of over 1 000 plant species
belonging to about 121 families, there are no description of their life
cycle except for sexual stage. The Gramineae are the most common host
plant for this genus. It has not been possible to isolate Phyllachora
taxa and grow them on the artificial media, therefore species
delimitation of the fungi so far has only been based studies of the
morphology of the sexual reproductive structures on the host plants.
However, due to lack of a consistent species criterion as well as
overlapping morphological characteristics, different taxonomic systems
have caused a great deal of taxonomic confusion. In this study, the DNA
of Phyllachora was successfully extracted from the ascomata carefully
harvest from its host tissues. Taxonomy of Phyllachora was revised based
on ITS and LSU regions sequences derived from 131 specimens from 47 host
species, belong to four subfamilies, 12 tribes of Gramineae.
Phylogenetic analysis indicate that each Phyllachora species was
restricted to a single host species, except P. pogonatheri and P.
chloridis-virgatae, which occurred on two host species of the same
genus, respectively. A high degree of host specificity was revealed in
graminicolous Phyllachora species, suggest that identification of
Phyllachora species can be determined based on the host species. Ten
well-supported groups, each occurring on the host species from same
genus, subtribe, tribe, subfamily of the Gramineae, were identified in
the taxa analysis in this study, which suggests a close affinity between
Phyllachora and the Gramineae in their evolution. Based on the single
nomenclature for fungi, 29 new species are proposed in Phyllachora
supported by molecular data in the present study. The best way for
identifying these species was combining host identity with molecular
markers such as ITS and LSU. This study has identified the need for
worldwide taxonomic revision of the graminicolous Phyllachora species.
